headline: Kamala Harris rejects criticism of 'identity politics'
subHeadline: Democratic senator from California says critics use phrase to 'minimize and marginalize'; reaction and analysis on 'The Five.'

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello, everyone. I'm Dana Perino along with Tammy Bruce, Richard Fowler, Jesse Watters, and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is "The Five." President Trump hitting the campaign trail in Ohio over the weekend and predicting a possible red wave in the midterms. This comes ahead of a hotly contested special election in the buckeye state's 12th district tomorrow.

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.sentences: They're talking about this blue wave. I don't think so. You win, and you're a little complacent, but, I mean, that was two years ago. So, I just said why? But we have the greatest economy in the history of our country. We have things that have never happened before. And, look, if the Democrats get in, they're going to raise your taxes. You're going to have crime all over the place. You're going to have people pouring across the border. So why would that be a blue wave? I think it could be a red wave.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The economy is a big plus for the president, that's 3.9 percent unemployment rate, it's the lowest for a July of a midterm year since 1966. Meanwhile, Democrats are taking a different approach. Senator Kamala Harris is speaking out against the use of this political phrase.

utterances.speaker: SEN. KAMALA HARRIS, D-CALIF.
utterances.sentences: I have a problem, guys, with that phrase, identity politics, because, let's be clear, when people say that, it's a pejorative. That phrase is used to divide and it is used to distract. Its purpose is to minimize and marginalize issues that impact all of us. It is used to try to shut us up.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right, Greg, and I have to go to you on that because you talk a lot about identity politics and how that helps divide the country, and she's saying, it's actually, if you say that, then you're being divisive.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Well, here's -- that was a very powerful - - I mean, if you agree with her, she's very persuasive. I have to say she's a strong speaker. I do disagree with everything she is saying, but I have to say the way she said it was pretty strong. Identity politics used to be a rallying cry for the left. It was a positive thing. Now when you mention it, it's an insult.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And the reason is because, ultimately, the consequences of identity politics is putting their group before the individual. And what happens is everybody who in their specific groups then have to feel that their group is somehow more important than the other group, so what you end up having are warring factions. And you're seeing it a lot of times where one group accuses another group of cultural appropriation, and another group accused that group of something else. Ultimately, it's going to turn on itself. This is why Trump won was because he was talking about one identity politics which was American. Now, then you have the left saying no, that's racist, because what you're really saying is white when you're talking about America. That's the consequence of identity politics is what they're saying is that if you are white, you're part of the oppressor group. So when you say identity politics, you're obviously racist. So that's -- nothing good can come from identity politics because in its heart, it's about division.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Tammy, welcome to "The Five."

utterances.speaker: TAMMY BRUCE, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Thank you, pleasure to be here.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: . it was a cry of a different message, right? So, President Trump is at a rally, that's a different scene for him. He loves it. He's into the crowd. Can you contrast that with Kamala Harris who was giving a speech at network nation? What do you think about the way that they're both setting things up?

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: Well, her attempt to retreat from identity politics, which they've relied on for decades, tells you that they've noticed it's not working. They've seen something internally that tells them we've got to stop this. And, actually, independent women's voice, which on the president and McLaughlin survey shows that 85 percent of people don't care, as an example, about gender. They're not going to base their vote on gender. Yet, that's what all of 2016 was really. Vote for Hillary, she'll be the first woman president. Or vote for this person, it will be the first of this thing or the other thing. Americans are not caring because they've realized that that's false. It doesn't work. So her position is, well, this is now not working. We've relied on this. Let's retreat a bit. The president just being consistent, it was what the campaign was. We're all in this together. The numbers prove that's correct. All of the unemployment numbers we know, of course, are extraordinary now. That everyone's boat has been lifted. It's the thing that he promised. And it's based on all of us -- actually, not seeing each other differently, but seeing each other as a neighbor. That's what resonates with the American people and that's why it's working.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Richard, I imagine you disagree. I will give you the floor, you can tell us why.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Don't give him the floor. Just give him the table.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: RICHARD FOWLER, GUEST CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: I'll take the floor and the table for $200. So, here's my take on this. So, here -- I think what Senator Harris was trying to say that she said very eloquently is this. When you fix an issue that -- for example, plaguing the African-American community, you help all Americans. When you properly fund public education, you help all Americans. When you fix our broken immigration system, you help all Americans. And you make sure that everybody has the right to vote without disenfranchisement, you help all Americans. So, it's not identity politics to make sure America works for everybody, no matter their color, no matter their race, no matter their sexuality, no matter their zip code, and I think that's the fight the Democrats are having.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Don't you think that.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: What we have in the White House is a president who only acknowledge a proud month as a thing. And we're still fighting for LGBTQ rights, right? You have a president in the White House.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Who also accept a gay marriage before Obama did.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: But you also have a president in the White House who gets into fights with NFL players or gets into fights with LeBron James.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He gets to fight with Hillary Clinton. He gets to fight with everybody. He gets to fight with Rosie O'Donnell.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That doesn't hurt any particular group when he's fighting with.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: I think if you talk to the African-American community they would say when you pick on LeBron James for opening a school in Akron, Ohio, you're picking on the entire African-American community.

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: He didn't pick on him because he opened up a school. He picked on him because LeBron James picked on Donald Trump, and that's.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And also, it was to make fun of Don Lemon.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We know Trump doesn't take the high road. He gets in the dirt and he fights it out.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Just saying.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK. But you should be used to it. It's two years.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: I am.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: . going on eight. So, I think the identity politics thing is they're looking for differences, as Tammy said, instead of everything that unites us. And the Democratic Party they have coalitions, and they've group these coalitions together for electoral victories based on their identity. And what they do is they have these groups and they say these groups have grievances, and we're going to correct those grievances, we're going to right those wrongs or right those injustices, and we're going to take -- and use the government to do that by redistributing wealth and benefits. But what they do is they say everything that's wrong that's plaguing these identity groups is the fault of Republicans. It's not the groups fault. It's not the economy's fault. It's not something that has nothing to do with Republicans. It's all the Republicans fault. So they demonize the Republicans and create a war. There's a war in women. There's a war in minorities. There's a war on Muslims. And a lot of Republicans don't go out every day and wake up, eat breakfast, and say how can I wage war on other people in this country? They go to work. They get their money. And they don't want the government to keep all of it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Can I play a couple sound -- pieces of sound for you and --. I'm actually going to play this thought back-to-back, one is a senate candidates -- Republican senate candidate in Michigan, that primary election is tomorrow. And the other is from -- you know her well, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, who was in the same state of Michigan campaigning for somebody else over the weekend.

utterances.speaker: JOHN JAMES, MICHIGAN SENATE CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: I don't have a black message. I don't have a white message. I have a red, white, and blue message. I have a message of everybody achieving the American dream.

utterances.speaker: ALEXANDRIA OCASIO-CORTEZ, NEW YORK CONGRESSIONAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: We can say that a Muslim man can be the first governor, that can be the first Muslim governor in this country, in the Midwest, and we don't have to be afraid of some other that won't vote for him because we know that ten years ago, they voted for a man named Barack Hussein Obama.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Tammy, your thoughts on that.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: Look, and she uses it right there, she's some other, casting immediately everyone else as the other. Now, look, this is why it's not working and why Senator Harris is troubled. The Harvard-Harris poll showed a ten-point boost of approval for the president by Hispanics. And Rasmussen showing last year the president was at 15 percent approval among African-Americans. Today, he's at 29 percent. So you're looking at a trajectory where groups that have been protected are saying, wait a minute, we are the same. The money is the same, the amount of money that we're getting at the tax cuts. We've got a job that's actually not delivering pizza. It's actually a real good professional job.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Tammy, when have African-Americans have been protected? I mean, we're getting shot in the street by police with no accountability. When are we being protected?

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: I think.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, that's the C-block, Richard.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah, and that's not true, by the way. There's a lot of accountability.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Eric Garner. Eric Garner was choked to death.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Why don't you look at the -- look at the research of who's doing the shooting, Richard. You can slip that in, but that.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: Very good example right now with those numbers for African- Americans. We immediately go to fear and victimhood. That's what we're rejecting.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Oh, because -- yeah, I'm very fearful when I get pulled over by police. I'm very fearful.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. So here's the bottom line, we're taking about identity politics. Let's say you want to have a discussion with somebody by identity politics and you say I'm willing to listen to you and I want to know, and I agree with you. What do you get? You don't get the answer because it's never enough. The idea of identity politics is that as you are the oppressor and they're the oppressed, so there's actually no end in sight. So, if you say will you take our help? I would like to help you with this. That will not be enough. If you see any public disturbance between -- either with Antifa or activists, these are people who are not interested in a discussion, all right? So that's why people say, when they're talking about identity politics, they can't have a discussion because it never ends. They're never happy. Identity politics is not about solutions, all right? It's about undoing civilization.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: . because that same argument made about the KKK. They're not trying to have a discussion with me about how to be less racist.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I agree with you there. Antifa is like the KKK. That's a red herring.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: When you talked to every day African-Americans they would say -- or you talked to every day brown folks they would say high quality in public schools, investments in our community, opportunities in our community.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: Every American said that.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: Every American wants that.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: And still fighting for that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Everybody is fighting for it.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: We're all fighting for it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I want to ask Jesse one last thing, which is that President Trump -- he has a way of basically disrupting everything, so you have Republicans across the country trying to lower expectations going into Ohio 12 tomorrow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So that they can hopefully, you know, beat expectations. He says forget all that. He's like raising expectations and expecting a red wave in November.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They need a red wall because it shouldn't be this close here in Ohio. This is a district that they've won, the Republicans, I think, for decades going back to the '30s. Now it's tied. You know the Democrats running away from Nancy Pelosi. He's keeping it on kitchen table issues, education costs, and health care costs. And he doesn't really even mention Donald Trump that much. The Republican is a little bit older. Not as charismatic. So he's got a little personality problem there. And now the national media is coming in big time. They started going positive and touting the president's success, and now they're just smearing this Democrat. They're linking him to Elizabeth Warren, calling her Pocahontas. They're going dirty late, so that means they're worried about it. But I think the Republicans are going to hang on, but if the Democrat does win it's going to give the Democrats a lot of momentum going into the midterms.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And get this, no matter what happens tomorrow, they both run again against each other in November. So, we'll be back talking about Ohio 12. President Trump continuing to attack the media, and his new tweet is creating all kinds of controversy, next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: President Trump taking aim at the media, yet, again, with a new round of blistering attacks this weekend.

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.sentences: You know what we've done is -- they even say, it really has been, as you say, amazing. It's been a miracle to a lot of people. It's been a miracle. Because I campaigned and I purposely didn't mention the kind of numbers that we're achieving because I didn't want to be accused of exaggeration, right, by the fake news media. They're so dishonest. These are among the most dishonest human beings you will ever meet.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The president also whipping up media hysterics with this tweet, quote, fake news reporting, a complete fabrication, that I am concerned about the meeting my wonderful son, Donald, had in Trump Tower. This was a meeting to get information on an opponent, totally legal and done all the time in politics. And it went nowhere. I did not know about it. Many of the press are claiming it's a stunning omission. But some have pointed out Trump's tweet isn't that different from what he said a year ago.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I think from a practical standpoint, most people would have taken that meeting. It's called opposition research or even research into your opponent. I've had many people. I have only been in politics for two years, but I've had many people call up O.G., we have information on this factor or this person or, frankly, Hillary. That's very standard in politics.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right, Dana, I was reading the Washington Post.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Were you?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: . over the weekend, and Marc Thiessen had a great column.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I want to bring this. GUTFELD: What section of the paper he's in?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It would be A2.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And he asked this question, he said what's the difference between what Donald Jr. did at the Trump Tower meeting and what Hillary Clinton did? And one of the main differences, he points out, is that Hillary Clinton actively solicited Russian dirt on an opponent by paying that cut out in Britain to get it from Russian sources. Donald Trump Jr. didn't solicit anything. The Russians came to him. Do you see the difference there?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: No, I don't see the difference at all.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: How could you not, Richard? I drove that right through your head.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: How simple can I make it, Richard?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: It's more like ships passing in the night, because the facts are completely different.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What are the facts.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Even in the email that Don -- I'm getting ready to tell you if you allow me to do that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm ready to listen.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Great. That's wonderful. So, even in the emails that Don Jr. released there was somebody -- like, we have somebody from -- connected to Putin, who is a lawyer in the Kremlin, and she has all this information on Hillary, would you meet with her? At that particular point -- yes, in that particular point in time that's where it becomes illegal.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What is the law.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: That's the federal.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Did he accept them?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: In accepting the meeting, one would argue.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The meeting is not information, and the law clearly states.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: I'm going to give you examples.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Because I have the law right here. Two U.S. code, 301121, nothing about meetings. It is about a donation or a contribution. And what came of the meeting? Zilch, Richard. Zilch. There's no crime there.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Let me make a point.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Am I right, Tammy, or am I right?

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: Here's what -- this is the entire argument. This does happen all the time, right? The big differences -- well, obviously, it's happened twice here. You've got a meeting with people looking for dirt. But then you've got the DNC -- but then you've got the DNC, as you've noted, paying money for information from the Russians, while her husband is getting a $500,000 paycheck for Russian speech, while she's making deals to get 20 percent of our uranium.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: But here is what has been, I think, a very good point over the weekend as well, that all of this pointing at Donald Trump is about really projections. That it's all the things the Democrats have been doing with the Russians, within that framework, to distract from that. It's a typical tactic. You accused your opponent of what you been doing so that nobody turns around to look at you. That's what's happening.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Dana, what you think about the latest iteration of the Trump Jr. Tower scandal?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Maybe it's exactly what the president said last year, but it's not what Sekulow, his lawyer said. And this weekend he had to say I was given bad information. I passed along bad information. And he won't elaborate. But, you know, that seems to be a recurring problem in this situation.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: He threw himself under the bus.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I am a broken record. I was actually going to write down, I'm a broken record.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: If I were home watching this, my head would explode because I would not care. And especially if I were a retired executive who worked in business who probably took half a half a dozen different meetings a day in your building. And I've said this to myself as an editor of a number of magazines, I took meetings with people I didn't even know or I sent people to meetings. It wasn't a big deal. You didn't care. Somebody come back and say, yeah, that guy turned out to be a drug dealer. I didn't know he was a drug dealer. He said he wanted to buy advertising. People have meetings all the time. They send their lowly assistance or whoever is around to these meetings. It drives me crazy that this is something that is somehow bigger than an actual candidate. Buying dirt sight unseen from the Russians through a British spy? That this -- getting a 20 minute meeting that you don't even give a damn about is somehow -- what also gets me about the media, a lot of these people have never worked in business before, so they don't understand this but they make phone call to you. A reporter would make a phone call to you to tell you or ask you about dirt about your coworker, all right? They are doing the same exact kind of thing. Every reporter that has written a thing about the media has done this kind of thing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No one is calling you about dirt on me, right?

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: To your point about people not caring.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Everybody takes the call, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: Literary, you're right about people not caring. Gallup did the list about the most important issue you're facing, what you care about, Russia didn't even -- it got an asterisk.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: . below everything else in the world.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They care more about Jesse's hair. We've proved this.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Against my better judgment, I'm going to give Richard the short last word. Short.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: I'll be very brief. This is not a business, this is actually campaigning. Campaigns are governed by law. The law says you can't take foreign contributions. Every time a foreign entity has come to a campaign, they've usually called the FBI. In 2000, it happened to Al Gore campaign.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: How come they didn't do it?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: What Don Jr. should have done.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Should have?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: . call the FBI.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: How come he didn't? Let me ask you, why do you think he didn't? No, no, no, why do you think he didn't? Because he didn't know. They're not politicians, Richard. They're not politicians. They're businessmen. They take meetings.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Ignorance of the law is not a defense.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, no, it's actually isn't a defense in this case because they didn't know.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: And you know who did know, the FBI.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And lastly, Clinton paid for Russian dirt.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You said he was going to get the last word.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Imagine if she won.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Deafening silence from liberals after a wave of gun violence sweeps Chicago this weekend.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: All right. A shocking level of violence this weekend in Chicago, police say 11 people were killed and dozens more were shot over the three-day span. Democrat Mayor Rahm Emanuel is partially blaming the number of firearms on the streets despite the city's tough regulations.

utterances.speaker: CHICAGO MAYOR RAHM EMANUEL
utterances.sentences: There are too many guns on the streets, too many people with criminal records on the street, and there is a shortage of values about what is right, what is wrong.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: Well, meanwhile, the typical liberal outrage is mostly nonexistent here. Should we be surprised? And, you know, a lot of people with that statement, the kind of the heads were crashing onto that desks because it was, kind of, didn't make a lot of sense, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, what I noticed was earlier, Giuliani made a mistake, right? He inverted the injuries and the murders so that -- he thought -- I think he said that 59 people were murdered and so he got -- so what I noticed from that was that Giuliani's mistake in his numbers got more press in the media than the actual deaths, which I think these were eight or nine.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So the mistake that Giuliani made was more outrageous to the people that have been ignoring what's been unfolding in Chicago for years. That this is actually the story that Giuliani screwed up -- so the thing -- so I'm starting to think, well, maybe Giuliani, actually, by screwing up, did Chicago a favor because finally people are actually talking about it. The fact is some major flaws in the media about this. One, they need a singular spectacle, mass shooting or a missing teen, but this -- this just keeps begetting violence because this is a continuing unfolding event. They just treat it like the weather. Like, 69 and cloudy, 54 injured, you know, in one area. And because it's in a cordoned off area of Chicago, the wealthy don't have to worry about it. The politicians don't have to worry about it. They don't care. And, you know, you've got problems with sentencing. People are on the street. You've got to deal with this stuff. But, you know what, as long as it keeps going and it doesn't bother them, it's OK.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: If they want to talk about, they'd have to discuss what the solution is. And they think they've applied the solution, which is the banning of guns, making guns virtually impossible to get. But it's gang activity and gang violence. Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I didn't hear that as the only solution today from them. I mean, the chief of police is taking about the breakdown of trust between the police and.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And Rahm Emanuel talks about that there's a lack of values. That's not a government solution.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Like, he's not saying that there's a magic government solution that can happen. Like, that's actually a conservative position.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, but remember. Remember, what was his -- this is a guy who went after Chick-Fil-A over values.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I get it. This is obviously a lot more important than Chick-Fil- A, and they have a huge problem there. But I don't think they're blind to it. And I think that the new chief of police also, he said that they were going to be conducting these coordinated enforcement missions. Like, they need our help, not our condemnation. And so I hope that -- the president has offered to help Chicago. I hope that Mayor Emanuel will take him up on it. Because people -- one of the reasons that not more people died is because our trauma surgeons are really good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's -- it's a sobering fact.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That is a fact.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But they should be able to not have to do that on a weekend.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: In the '70s, the numbers would be --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It would have been 59.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, it would have. Yes.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: This is really -- we do get very upset, understandably, about the horror of a mass shooting. This is like a mass shooting every weekend, and we do just kind of avoid it, because maybe we've gotten used to it. Is that part of the problem, why the media ignores it? Because they just generally do.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, the media needs a villain in a case like this. And they can't have Rahm be the villain, because he's a Democrat and he's protected. And they can't have an anonymous gang member be a villain, because that doesn't fit the bill. And it is like the weather. But -- like Greg said, but they've found their villain, and it's Rudy Giuliani. So what they could do -- and there's and opportunity for the media to do, is treat this like a real humanitarian crisis. Like a hurricane or like a school shooting. They flood the zone with TV reporters. They bring an anchor to Chicago. They send undercover people. They talk with local pastors and leadership. And they can really shine a spotlight on something like that. And what that will do, it will hold the mayor accountable. It will shame local politicians into actually doing something. And it might bring more philanthropists and charity, athletes, and celebrities into Chicago and see if we can fix this mess. Because it's really sad.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: And of course we're looking at, everyone generally agrees we're dealing with gang shootings, who just drive by and shoot into gatherings, especially during the summer. You can shoot a lot of people all at once there, so we've got a gang problem. Is this why we're still dealing with this and there's no major national outrage?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Well, I think to some extent, I agree with Dana, I agree with Jesse a little bit, in that I think this should be a main -- a main media story, because what's happening in the streets of Chicago is a genocide. One of our colleagues, Gianno Caldwell, has been on the ground there for a couple of days, covering what's happening there. But I think to say that the liberals have been silent is -- is a farce, because thousands of people in Chicago have been protesting and have been talking about the lack of security and -- for the people and the lack of opportunity. You cannot solve gangs without dealing with the root cause. And to deal -- the root cause of gangs is because there's no opportunity in these communities.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: These young men have nothing to do. The schools are not working as though they should be, because they're not being properly funded by the mayor. And thus, they see the gangs. They see them as role models, and they join the gangs.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: And there haven't been jobs.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: We've got to deal with the fact --

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: -- that there's no opportunity, and we've also got to deal with what Dana brought up, is there's a breakdown of trust between the community and police. Part of it was because of Laquan McDonald, who was shot 16 times by the police. And he -- there was a cover-up with the mayor involved, with paying the family off and no -- nobody saw the takes until it was finally pushed to be out.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: But there's people that are doing good work, and we've got to, you know, help them. We've got to get to the root problem.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: We have touched, I think, on all the things that we need to deal with. And obviously, this is going to continue here. Now, up next, Greg breaks down how an alleged drone attack on the Venezuelan president could be a new frontier in terrorism.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. A drone attack broke up Venezuelan President Maduro's speech on Saturday. Here's tape of his soldiers reacting heroically to the attack. Looks like they spotted Air Force One. So two points to learn from this: First, Venezuela is a socialist paradise that was once rich, meaning if you like Bernie, this could be your future. Someone should page Alexandria and the Democrats. Hyper-inflation, depression, human rights violations, food shortages. There's your happy tomorrow. You, too, could eat your own zoo animals. Your currency could be worth less than toilet paper, except you couldn't buy toilet paper. Play your Bernie card right, and your medicine could vanish, your hospitals close. And for safety, you could do what Venezuelans do: Move to Colombia. Think it can't happen? Venezuela was once the most prosperous country in South America. But boy, they traded it all in for a dime-store socialist. The point of socialism: to find something good made by somebody else, take it for yourself. It's shoplifting as a political theory. You convince poor people to give up everything they have to beat the crap out of them if they ask for it back. They've been doing this for a century now. Socialism is even older than Bernie. And it doesn't work either. Second thing: The attack was by drone, equipped with C-4. I've been talking about this forever. Terror married to Amazon technology. It's a new scary reality. You can fret about it. The experts are already there. They don't want to ban socialists; they want to ban drones. Frankly, you can't ban either. But any smarty-pants knows which one is worse. Dana, I sat here and I said, technology in terror is the next wave.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: For years you've said that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I've said it since the early '70s when "The Five" first started. Remember that?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes. It's been good working for you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We're at almost our 50th year. And I tell you, your surgery. You look just like you -- you look just like you did when the show started.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean, it's been -- yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You're on thin ice, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Anyway. You get my point.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, I do get your point. Mary Anastasia O'Grady, I'm sure your read her column today in The Wall Street Journal, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: After The Washington Post.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: She said that, for Maduro, if you -- if you want to murder Maduro, you need to get in line. Because there are so many people who think his leadership has been exactly how you just described it. It has absolutely destroyed the country. But also, she said another thing, which is that Cuba is basically controlling this country. So everyone is basically dealing with a situation where, remember, during the Obama administration, he tried to make that overture, tried to change everything. It didn't actually work. Because you can't just make an overture without making recommendations or insisting on changes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And you won't get any of those changes. And then the drone thing, I'll let other people talk about that, but it's scary as you know what.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Richard, you said -- we were talking about this in the break. I'm very pro-drone, but I do think -- and you are, too. But -- because drones save lives in war. You lose -- use fewer soldiers. And you -- the collateral damage is less. But the down side is, other people can have drones and use them for evil. So where do you stand on this?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: I'm OK with when we use drones in high-combat situations or our men and women, our veterans, our current armed forces are at risk. Right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: So situations like Iraq and Fallujah, if we had more drones, there'd be less American deaths. I'm against drones in the use for surveillance purposes. When they use it to surveil Americans, when they're used to surveil -- like, you know, that type of thing. But the ideal of having drones in war zones where we can have people sitting in Omaha, Nebraska, managing our drones, that's great because then we don't lose valuable American lives.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, I agree.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: That's going to naturally move to robots then, too. Talking about this. Why keep it in the air? Why not just send, you know, the robots to go do, you know, the action? And so it's still going to be -- the end result is somebody's going to die.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But more efficiently. The -- the great thing about technology is that they are -- you can -- they don't sleep. They don't get distracted. And you have them facing your target.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: The operator well, to some degree.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They have 60 for a drone.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: The thing about Venezuela, there is a concern that, in fact, this was not something that was done from the outside. That he was doing this himself. The big surprise was that the military reacted the way they did. So if you find that there's military people suddenly disappearing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You'll know they are.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: You'll know what happened.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I can't blame them. What do -- the military, they want to defend of failing, dying system? I don't know, Jesse. Your thoughts?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Not the greatest military discipline I've seen on display. Not a good look.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: Somebody's in trouble right now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's going to embolden the Colombians. They're just going to take over Venezuela.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know, you bring up -- OK, more people -- I've read this fact. I hope it's right. More people are fleeing Venezuela than people are fleeing Syria.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, there's no one really left to leave Syria, No. 1.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And the people that are fleeing Venezuela aren't coming to America and talking about how great socialism is. This's for sure. I think this was the scariest monologue that you every did.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm actually terrified of this. If you have a jihadist in the United States, and he straps some munition to some jury-rigged drone that he bought off the Internet, goes and flies it over a football game, how are you going to prevent that?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: When did you start watching "The Five"?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I've been saying that. I've been saying that, that --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I don't listen to all your monologues.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It may have been before -- the idea of a drone married to a bio agent, say, anthrax.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I mean this is -- you're right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Fly it over a football field. You can kill thousands.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: That 50 years of partnership, "The Gutfeld Monologues," that's great.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: When the news broke on Saturday, the first thing I did is forward it to Greg, and I said, "Here we go."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: We didn't know what it was. I do think it could be possible that Maduro set this up for himself, because what did they have today? They had rallies of support for him today. And he needs that, because internally, people are mad.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: And there was no extended security zone for him. There was no, you know, extra coverage.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, you're forgetting about the jackets they were holding up over his head.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: The Kevlar jackets. I think only when we have our president outcome, you know, you put him in, like, a little cage, the bulletproof cage that they're in, even during the inauguration. Clearly, they weren't prepared for this drone coming.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. A musician's flight ends on a sour note. Very clever, producer. Very clever, producer. Very clever.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: We all know how frustrating it can be to fly. For example, an American Airlines passenger got kicked off the flight because of the size of her cello. The outraged musician says she was booted after the crew claimed the plane was too small for her $33,000 instrument, even though she had already bought a seat. The airline calls it a miscommunication. Our very own fellow "Fiver" Greg posted an interesting tweet about his trip back from Texas this weekend. "Flights can be delayed at times indefinitely because people flush things down the toilet that shouldn't be flushed. Don't be that person."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: What happened?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Greg, who was that person?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, first, the solution is for anybody, for the woman, play the flute. You save so much money. It's a tiny little instrument. And actually, it's more enjoyable than the cello. I had a great flight. It was fantastic. The people -- I'm always against people tweeting against airlines, because I think it's petty. That's why I didn't mention the airline.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Somebody flushed something down the toilet, and that delayed a flight. We always think -- I mean, what delays flights? There are so many variables. But the No. 1 thing is always weather. But you don't consider the thousand variables. And in this case, it was somebody -- you know, never flush anything down that's larger than a cocktail weenie. It's my rule for everything.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's a good rule.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Good rule.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: I was one of those people that tweets the airlines, because I think airlines should have good customer service and hundreds and hundreds of dollars a flight to Israel and they were 12 hours delayed. And I was, like, 12-hour delay? Is that even possible?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But they're looking out for you. It could be weather. It could be weather. They're trying to save your life.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: You know when they oversell the flight, and they're like, "Oh, we need five people to volunteer." Maybe you shouldn't have oversold the flight.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think people, like, over -- across the board, you had a good flight yesterday.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: A lot of people, we get where we need to go. But I think across the board, people are super frustrated with the airlines. With the actual planes, with the delays, with the overselling, with the cost of it all. And people want to go -- get where they're going. And they're extremely frustrated. I knew somebody who tried to get to Milwaukee for a bachelor party, but they ended up sending them down to Richmond. Like, well, how did we get to Milwaukee? And they said, "Well, you can't until Monday." So they missed the whole reason they left anyway and had to take a six-hour train back.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: You know, one of the big things, too, I think, that's hurting how people view airlines, are the animal issues. There are so many stories about the animals not making it. That becomes a problem. But then there's a very basic kind of thing. I was in -- on a flight in business class. I asked for a blanket, where you're supposed to get one. The flight attendant took it out of the overhead and threw it at me. And one other flight, which was -- Watters: Assault with a blanket.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Tweet the airline.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: Well, I tweeted at that point, and I tweeted about this other airline. It was so cold that -- and everyone was complaining this one flight attendant brought literally a water bottle with hot water in it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh, that works. I do that every day.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: Yes. This is like -- handing it to us. It was just not the best customer service. And you do expect, at least, to have, you know, some kind of, at least, not frozen air when you're flying.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Here's what I think. People need to take flying much more seriously. It's a sport, OK. It's an athletic event. There's a lot of people trying to get on the flight quickly, and you have people not paying attention. They're on their phones. They can't find their bags. Their bags are mislaid. Their kids are this way. This is like, once that flight opens up, you have your ticket ready. You scan it. You go. All right? And then you find your seat fast. Boom, you sit, buckle, blanket, overhead. Don't talk to anybody. Don't go to the bathroom. Nothing. Stop bothering other people and holding everything up.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Jesse, we're agreeing more these days. We're hanging out too much, America. Hanging out too much.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: You remember when a woman was not allowed on the plane because her children were in leggings. Do you think there's too much put on that about how you appear, how you're dressed? The girl was in leggings, and they wouldn't let her on the plane.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Like Spandex.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: She was on the voucher. She was on, like, a buddy system ticket. Do you think people should dress better when they get on planes? Because that's another.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: There used to be a time when you had to dress up to get on a plane.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: But now it's 2018, and you can wear whatever the hell you want.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know, it's sad. OK, because it's more affordable to fly. More people are flying. It's a bus in the sky. That's what it is. And therefore, people are dressing -- but people are dressing like slobs everywhere. Sweatpants are replacing khakis, and --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I have to admit something.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I have transitioned from dressing nice on flights to sweatpants and sneakers.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There you go.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Sweatpants? Sweatpants?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Stylish sweatpants.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Sweatpants and a hoodie.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: Because that's how bad the flights are. If you want some comfort, you're going to have to get it for yourself.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: The only thing I think airlines could do that would make life great is if you had a children's only section in the back of the plane. All the families could sit in the back of the plane, and those business travelers who don't want to hear the kids could sit in the front.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. I'm excited about my "One More Thing." So let's go.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: "One More Thing" is up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's time now for "One More Thing." I'm excited, because every summer there is a rodeo, and a county fair in Weston County. And I sponsor the Girls Saddle for whichever young girl wins a junior rodeo for the girls, I get them the saddle. Well, this is Jocelyn Pischke -- excuse me, Jocelyn Pischke. Her horse is Houdini.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: She won. She's only eight years old, but get this. It turns out she's my little cousin.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Aww.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Nepotism.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Take a look at this video to see if you can tell we're related.

utterances.speaker: JOCELYN PISCHKE, RODEO WINNER
utterances.sentences: Hi, Dana, this is me Jocelyn, and this is my horse, Houdini. We want to thank you so much for sponsoring the Jr. Girls all around a saddle. We're super, super excited. Aren't we, Houdini.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Congratulations to Jocelyn. I can't wait to see. Hopefully, we can get there next year. I might bring Jesse.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: A natural talker.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right, Jesse. I mean, Greg.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: She's like, a little press -- She's good. She's good. I hope she comes and visits me in New York. That means she could get on television.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. Very sexist, too.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Why?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: "Watters's World."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Sponsoring just a girl. Really, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, the girls' saddle.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: OK, whatever. Disgusting. All right. I want to thank everybody with the Barnes & Noble and Fort Worth and in Dallas to Woodland this weekend. I met so many awesome people, and they make you stuff. They make paintings and they give you things. And it's absolutely crazy. I think I must have met at least maybe 3,000 people. And just -- and lots of families. Everybody asking about "The Five." You know Darrell Evans from the San Francisco Giants. If you were a Giants fan of the '70s, you know Darrell Evans. He was, like, I think, a third baseman, if I remember. And I ran into my buddy Riley from Power Trip. This is for any metal bands who love "The Five," and liberals who hate the fact that Riley and I are buddies. I can't see that far -- oh, I'm talking to Dusty Hill from Z.Z. Top. That's his wife. I know, are these great pictures, Dana? I've got 600 of them.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK, we're going to move on, though. Guess what?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Guess what?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's a call-back.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: The whole point of this, I'm going to be at Huntington Book Review.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, Huntington.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Huntington, New York, Book Review tomorrow night.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes, you better go to that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That was the whole point.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK. Jesse now.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right. It's time for Jesse's "Eyebrow News."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We don't have an animation. We don't need one. Eyebrow beatdown at a Brooklyn salon. Someone didn't like how their eyebrows were done and whips out a broomstick and some fists. Look at that. Look at that. It's getting violent in the beauty salon.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's terrible.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. Everyone is OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Why are you showing this?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Because, listen, eyebrows are my beat, Dana. And if there's an eyebrow news in the media, I will cover it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You are first. Fair and balanced.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wow. All right, Richard. We have a minute left.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: All right. So this story, you can also check it out on my Instagram page, @RichardAFowler. The video is posted there. But this is a really cool story about a woman who was rejected from a nail salon because she had cerebral palsy. A Wal-Mart cashier saw it, They ran into the store, bought nail polish and did them.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Did the nails herself.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: But you can see the whole entire story on my Instagram page, @RichardAFowler, where you can catch the video and hear the story.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'm going to follow you right now.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: More good news from the cancer research community. There is a new drug that is 93 percent effective with kids' cancers, 75 percent effective with some rare adult cancers. The drug is called Larotrectinib. It has been approved by the FDA, and it's a breakthrough therapy drug. It is remarkable. I put this on social media. It goes viral, because you don't hear about the stuff these days. And anything you hear --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Got to get the word out.

utterances.speaker: BRUCE
utterances.sentences: -- may be attached to Trump. So that is the new drug. It's going to be helping kids do this kind of stuff, which is what kids should be doing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. Thanks for being here. Set your DVRs, never miss an episode of "The Five." She likes her coffee with sugar and cream. It's Shannon Bream.

utterances.speaker: SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS
utterances.sentences: It is soy, just to be clear.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Nailed it.

utterances.speaker: BREAM
utterances.sentences: Love it Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2018 CQ-Roll Call, Inc.
